An **orc**, o, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It serves as the corresponding "base" monster for player [orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(starting_race\) "Orc (starting race)").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
- [3 History](#History)
- [4 Origin](#Origin)
- [5 Variants](#Variants)
  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)
- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

Orcs are [not randomly generated](/wiki/Monster_creation "Monster creation"), but can appear in a game that has [Orcish Town](/wiki/Orcish_Town "Orcish Town") present - various named orcs may be among the [orcish monsters](/wiki/Orc_\(monster_attribute\) "Orc (monster attribute)") generated carrying looted items.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) Orcs can [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") to become [orc-captains](/wiki/Orc-captain "Orc-captain").

Orcs have a 1⁄2 chance of [generating with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") an [orcish helm](/wiki/Orcish_helm "Orcish helm"), and a separate 1⁄2 chance of being given an [orcish dagger](/wiki/Orcish_dagger "Orcish dagger") or a [scimitar](/wiki/Scimitar "Scimitar"), with an equal chance for each weapon.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

An [orc zombie](/wiki/Orc_zombie "Orc zombie") or [orc mummy](/wiki/Orc_mummy "Orc mummy") will leave an aged orc [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") behind upon death;[\[4\]](#cite_note-undead_to_corpse-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-make_corpse-5) player orcs that are killed and leave [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") will have a gnome corpse atop their grave, unless they were killed by certain monsters or else [stoned](/wiki/Stoning "Stoning") or [disintegrated](/wiki/Disintegrate "Disintegrate"). Orcs can be generated by zapping a [wand of undead turning](/wiki/Wand_of_undead_turning "Wand of undead turning") at an orc corpse *not* left by a mummy or zombie, or selecting orcs when reading a [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed") [scroll of genocide](/wiki/Scroll_of_genocide "Scroll of genocide").

## Strategy

"Plain" orcs are not too substantially different from [hobgoblins](/wiki/Hobgoblin "Hobgoblin") and [hill orcs](/wiki/Hill_orc "Hill orc") minus a slightly stronger weapon attack, and can be defeated with much of the same tactics. Pursuing any orcs you encounter during a game with Orcish Town is generally a good idea in order to nab the [candles](/wiki/Candle "Candle") and [gloves](/wiki/Gloves "Gloves") they may be carrying.

## History

The orc is one of the many monsters present in hack121 and Hack for PDP-11, variants of [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"). Orcs also appear in the initial bestiary for [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0"), and were present in each version up to [NetHack 2.3e](/wiki/NetHack_2.3e "NetHack 2.3e"). In its appearances, orcs often generated in hordes similar to [hill orcs](/wiki/Hill_orcs "Hill orcs") in modern *NetHack*. In [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"), the various types of orcs were introduced, alongside orc zombies and mummies, and the base orc was used for the purpose of generating corpses left by undead orcs;[\[6\]](#cite_note-6) they are also used to represent the bones of player orcs once starting races were introduced in [NetHack 3.3.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.3.0 "NetHack 3.3.0").

In hack121, orcs used the o glyph as in modern *NetHack*; in Hack for PDP-11, and from Hack 1.0 to NetHack 2.3e, orcs instead used the O glyph.

Starting in [NetHack 3.6.2](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.2 "NetHack 3.6.2"), named orcs begin appearing with Minetown loot in a dungeon where Orcish Town is generated, due to changes in how the loot-carrying monsters are generated.[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Orc](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orc "wikipedia:Orc")***

The orcs in *NetHack* are derived from *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, which in turn are based on their portrayal in the works of [J. R. R. Tolkien](/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien "J. R. R. Tolkien").

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), seventeen plain orcs are placed randomly around the outside of [Grund's Stronghold](/wiki/Grund%27s_Stronghold "Grund's Stronghold") at level creation.

In [NetHack-- 3.0.10](/wiki/NetHack--_3.0.10 "NetHack-- 3.0.10"), an ancestor of SLASH'EM, plain orcs could appear via random generation; this was not retained for [NetHack-- 3.1.3](/wiki/NetHack--_3.1.3 "NetHack-- 3.1.3"), but was made possible again in [SLASH 6](/wiki/SLASH_6 "SLASH 6").

## Encyclopedia entry

Orcs, bipeds with a humanoid appearance, are related to the  
goblins, but much bigger and more dangerous. The average orc  
is only moderately intelligent, has broad, muscled shoulders,  
a short neck, a sloping forehead and a thick, dark fur.  
Their lower eye-teeth are pointing forward, like a boar's.  
Female orcs are more lightly built and bare-chested. Not  
needing any clothing, they do like to dress in variegated  
apparels. Suspicious by nature, orcs live in tribes or  
hordes. They tend to live underground as well as above  
ground (but they dislike sunlight). Orcs can use all weapons,  
tools and armors that are used by men. Since they don't have  
the talent to fashion these themselves, they are constantly  
hunting for them. There is nothing a horde of orcs cannot  
use.

\[ het Boek van de Regels; Het Oog des Meesters ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/mkmaze.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 740](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkmaze.c#L740)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 397](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L397): *default orcish armor*
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 426](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L426): *default orcish weapons*
4. [↑](#cite_ref-undead_to_corpse_4-0) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 147](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L147): *Converting monster index of undead to corpses of their living counterparts*
5. [↑](#cite_ref-make_corpse_5-0) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 372](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L372): *Undead corpses and their ages are handled with other "special" death drops*
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [src/monst.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 624](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/monst.c#L624)
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [src/mkmaze.c in NetHack 3.6.2, line 804](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.2_Release/src/mkmaze.c#L804)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

An orc:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • is omnivorous.

Reference monst.c#line677

An orc, o, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. It serves as the corresponding "base" monster for player orcs.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 SLASH'EM
  • 6 Encyclopedia entry
  • 7 References

Generation

Orcs are not randomly generated, but can appear in a game that has Orcish Town present - various named orcs may be among the orcish monsters generated carrying looted items.[1] Orcs can grow up to become orc-captains.

Orcs have a 1⁄2 chance of generating with an orcish helm, and a separate 1⁄2 chance of being given an orcish dagger or a scimitar, with an equal chance for each weapon.[2][3]

An orc zombie or orc mummy will leave an aged orc corpse behind upon death;[4][5] player orcs that are killed and leave bones will have a gnome corpse atop their grave, unless they were killed by certain monsters or else stoned or disintegrated. Orcs can be generated by zapping a wand of undead turning at an orc corpse not left by a mummy or zombie, or selecting orcs when reading a cursed scroll of genocide.

Strategy

"Plain" orcs are not too substantially different from hobgoblins and hill orcs minus a slightly stronger weapon attack, and can be defeated with much of the same tactics. Pursuing any orcs you encounter during a game with Orcish Town is generally a good idea in order to nab the candles and gloves they may be carrying.

History

The orc is one of the many monsters present in hack121 and Hack for PDP-11, variants of Jay Fenlason's Hack. Orcs also appear in the initial bestiary for Hack 1.0, and were present in each version up to NetHack 2.3e. In its appearances, orcs often generated in hordes similar to hill orcs in modern NetHack. In NetHack 3.0.0, the various types of orcs were introduced, alongside orc zombies and mummies, and the base orc was used for the purpose of generating corpses left by undead orcs;[6] they are also used to represent the bones of player orcs once starting races were introduced in NetHack 3.3.0.

In hack121, orcs used the o glyph as in modern NetHack; in Hack for PDP-11, and from Hack 1.0 to NetHack 2.3e, orcs instead used the O glyph.

Starting in NetHack 3.6.2, named orcs begin appearing with Minetown loot in a dungeon where Orcish Town is generated, due to changes in how the loot-carrying monsters are generated.[7]

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Orc

The orcs in NetHack are derived from Dungeons & Dragons, which in turn are based on their portrayal in the works of J. R. R. Tolkien.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, seventeen plain orcs are placed randomly around the outside of Grund's Stronghold at level creation.

In NetHack-- 3.0.10, an ancestor of SLASH'EM, plain orcs could appear via random generation; this was not retained for NetHack-- 3.1.3, but was made possible again in SLASH 6.

Encyclopedia entry

Orcs, bipeds with a humanoid appearance, are related to the
goblins, but much bigger and more dangerous. The average orc
is only moderately intelligent, has broad, muscled shoulders,
a short neck, a sloping forehead and a thick, dark fur.
Their lower eye-teeth are pointing forward, like a boar's.
Female orcs are more lightly built and bare-chested. Not
needing any clothing, they do like to dress in variegated
apparels. Suspicious by nature, orcs live in tribes or
hordes. They tend to live underground as well as above
ground (but they dislike sunlight). Orcs can use all weapons,
tools and armors that are used by men. Since they don't have
the talent to fashion these themselves, they are constantly
hunting for them. There is nothing a horde of orcs cannot
use.

[ het Boek van de Regels; Het Oog des Meesters ]

References

  1. ↑ src/mkmaze.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 740
  2. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 397: default orcish armor
  3. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 426: default orcish weapons
  4. ↑ src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 147: Converting monster index of undead to corpses of their living counterparts
  5. ↑ src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 372: Undead corpses and their ages are handled with other "special" death drops
  6. ↑ src/monst.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 624
  7. ↑ src/mkmaze.c in NetHack 3.6.2, line 804

An '''orc''', {{monsym|orc}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It serves as the corresponding "base" monster for player [[Orc (starting race)|orcs]].

==Generation==
Orcs are [[Monster creation|not randomly generated]], but can appear in a game that has [[Orcish Town]] present - various named orcs may be among the [[orc (monster attribute)|orcish monsters]] generated carrying looted items.{{refsrc|src/mkmaze.c|740|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} Orcs can [[grow up]] to become [[orc-captain]]s.

Orcs have a {{frac|2}} chance of [[Monster starting inventory|generating with]] an [[orcish helm]], and a separate {{frac|2}} chance of being given an [[orcish dagger]] or a [[scimitar]], with an equal chance for each weapon.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|397|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=default orcish armor}}{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|426|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=default orcish weapons}}

An [[orc zombie]] or [[orc mummy]] will leave an aged orc [[corpse]] behind upon death;{{refsrc|src/mon.c|147|nethack=3.6.7|name="undead_to_corpse"|comment=Converting monster index of undead to corpses of their living counterparts}}{{refsrc|src/mon.c|372|nethack=3.6.7|name="make_corpse"|comment=Undead corpses and their ages are handled with other "special" death drops}} player orcs that are killed and leave [[bones]] will have a gnome corpse atop their grave, unless they were killed by certain monsters or else [[Stoning|stoned]] or [[disintegrate]]d. Orcs can be generated by zapping a [[wand of undead turning]] at an orc corpse ''not'' left by a mummy or zombie, or selecting orcs when reading a [[cursed]] [[scroll of genocide]].

==Strategy==
"Plain" orcs are not too substantially different from [[hobgoblin]]s and [[hill orc]]s minus a slightly stronger weapon attack, and can be defeated with much of the same tactics. Pursuing any orcs you encounter during a game with Orcish Town is generally a good idea in order to nab the [[candle]]s and [[gloves]] they may be carrying.

==History==
The orc is one of the many monsters present in hack121 and Hack for PDP-11, variants of [[Jay Fenlason's Hack]]. Orcs also appear in the initial bestiary for [[Hack 1.0]], and were present in each version up to [[NetHack 2.3e]]. In its appearances, orcs often generated in hordes similar to [[hill orcs]] in modern ''NetHack''. In [[NetHack 3.0.0]], the various types of orcs were introduced, alongside orc zombies and mummies, and the base orc was used for the purpose of generating corpses left by undead orcs;{{refsrc|src/monst.c|624|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} they are also used to represent the bones of player orcs once starting races were introduced in [[NetHack 3.3.0]].

In hack121, orcs used the {{white|o}} glyph as in modern ''NetHack''; in Hack for PDP-11, and from Hack 1.0 to NetHack 2.3e, orcs instead used the {{white|O}} glyph.

Starting in [[NetHack 3.6.2]], named orcs begin appearing with Minetown loot in a dungeon where Orcish Town is generated, due to changes in how the loot-carrying monsters are generated.{{refsrc|src/mkmaze.c|804|version=NetHack 3.6.2}}

==Origin==
{{Wikipedia|Orc}}
The orcs in ''NetHack'' are derived from ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'', which in turn are based on their portrayal in the works of [[J. R. R. Tolkien]].

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], seventeen plain orcs are placed randomly around the outside of [[Grund's Stronghold]] at level creation.

In [[NetHack-- 3.0.10]], an ancestor of SLASH'EM, plain orcs could appear via random generation; this was not retained for [[NetHack-- 3.1.3]], but was made possible again in [[SLASH 6]]. 

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|
Orcs, bipeds with a humanoid appearance, are related to the
goblins, but much bigger and more dangerous.  The average orc
is only moderately intelligent, has broad, muscled shoulders,
a short neck, a sloping forehead and a thick, dark fur.
Their lower eye-teeth are pointing forward, like a boar's.
Female orcs are more lightly built and bare-chested.  Not
needing any clothing, they do like to dress in variegated
apparels.  Suspicious by nature, orcs live in tribes or
hordes.  They tend to live underground as well as above
ground (but they dislike sunlight).  Orcs can use all weapons,
tools and armors that are used by men.  Since they don't have
the talent to fashion these themselves, they are constantly
hunting for them.  There is nothing a horde of orcs cannot
use.
|[ het Boek van de Regels; Het Oog des Meesters ]
